importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The daily screenings of Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge were nearly discontinued in 2015 due to public backlash, which led to the reversal of that decision and ensured the film's continued run at the Maratha Mandir theatre.

The film Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge was first released on October 20, 1995, marking the beginning of its legacy as India’s longest-running film, which continues to draw audiences to the Maratha Mandir theatre.
The article was published on October 19, 2025, to mark the 30th anniversary of the film's daily screenings at the Maratha Mandir theatre in Mumbai, highlighting its enduring cultural significance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The film was released in 1995 and has since maintained uninterrupted daily screenings for over 30 years, making it a landmark in Indian cinema history.
Between 2015 and 2025, the film faced a potential discontinuation of screenings, but public demand and cultural significance led to its revival, reinforcing its status as a cultural touchstone.

keyTakeAways: Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (DDLJ) is India’s longest-running film, with uninterrupted daily screenings for over 30 years at the Maratha Mandir theatre in Mumbai.
The film, released in 1995, redefined modern Hindi romance by portraying love transcending traditional and cultural boundaries.
Daily screenings continue to attract hundreds of viewers, including university students and young couples, with peak attendance on Sundays.
The film’s climax, where the heroine runs into her lover’s arms on a moving train, is a widely celebrated moment that still evokes strong emotional responses.
The film has influenced real-life relationships, with viewers citing it as a romantic inspiration and even as a wedding inspiration.
Despite being nearly discontinued in 2015, fan backlash ensured the film’s continued screening, underscoring its deep cultural resonance.
Film critic Baradwaj Rangan describes the film as a cultural monument representing the tension between traditional and modern Indian values.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 30-year-long tradition of daily screenings at Mumbai’s Maratha Mandir theatre celebrates the enduring popularity of the Bollywood romance film Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (DDLJ), which premiered in 1995 and has since become India’s longest-running film. The film, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, redefined modern Hindi romance by depicting a love story that transcends traditional boundaries, resonating across generations. Despite being nearly discontinued in 2015, fan backlash ensured its continuation. The film continues to draw large audiences, especially young couples and students, with emotional reactions to its climactic scene, and has even influenced real-life relationships and weddings. Critics like Baradwaj Rangan describe it as a cultural monument representing the tension between traditional and modern Indian values, underscoring its lasting impact on Indian society.
title: Iconic Bollywood romance marks 30 years of nonstop run at Mumbai theatre
